I bought this game just to see how bad it was. I mean, 'overwhelmingly negative' is not a rating I see very often. Here are my thoughts.

Here's what you're getting into if you play it: A dystopian space voyage through vaguely H.R. Giger-themed terrain.

A loop of 80's synth that will quickly begin to rot your soul.

Neon-colored, hard to read text with very amateurish voice acting.

A story of a nun on a mission to uncover the reason behind a galactic monastery's disappearance.

A space ship that uses a hallucinogenic drug-powered laser to mine bible verses from meteorites.

Riding a container of drugs through a bullet-hell style side scrolling shooter while gunning down crosses.

A final showdown with a godlike creature that makes it hard to tell what exactly the message of this game even is.
Is it a bad game?

No, not at all considering the dozens of space shooters that demand your 5 dollars without any sort of charm or originality. (Here's looking at you, Blast Em.)

The visuals are weird, the gameplay is janky, and I probably won't play it ever again. What this game did that so many games I've played have not, however, was give me an experience I will remember, and I think that's worth a positive review.

PS - I got this game for 50 cents. If you paid more than that, disregard this entire review. You ♥♥♥♥ed up.

reviewText:
Uriel’s Chasm is a game that many people will not love and will not enjoy. It’s a different sort of game and it doesn’t happen very often that I play a game this weird. Naturally, the word ‘weird’ can be interpreted both ways here, but I mean it in a negative sense, I’m afraid.

The game is approximately 30 minutes long and it’s unclear, unfocused, amateuristic  and, above all, pretentious.
It’s supposedly about religion and faith. That’s what the ‘story’ led me to believe anyway. But this story mostly consists of (seemingly random) Bible verses, sometimes spoken by a person that clearly has no passion doing this.
The FMVs are also uninteresting and, in my opinion, hardly add anything to the entire game.

Gameplay-wise the game consists of several genres; you start the game in a ship shown for a top-down perspective and it’s your goal to collect more faith than what’s in the garden. This can be done by shooting meteorites while also avoiding them and one, large, rotating monster (I think ?).
Meteorites will sometimes drop bible verses, which you can then collect to increase your faith meter. You have to take into account that moving will decrease your fuel meter and hitting enemies will decrease your faith meter. Shooting your guns will also deplete your ammo meter. If any meter completely depletes it is game over.
If you’ve collected enough faith the game will continue to the next part which is a side-scrolling shooter. The goal there is shoot your enemies or to just avoid their gunfire and kill the boss at the end of the level. Looks simple, but the collision detection is poor and as a result is sometimes fairly frustrating.
The last part is a platformer. You just jump around finding trees/crosses that show you verses from the Bible. There are no enemies and you can’t die here. But the level does rotate so it might be a bit confusing and disorienting to some. This should be simple enough for most of us.
Like I said, all of this takes approximately 30 minutes or 1 hour max if maybe you don’t play many games.

The graphics are retro and in 2D, which look ok. Some of the graphics are a bit hideous but overall it all looks decent enough.
And despite what you would think the music is pretty good. But that’s about the only real thing I enjoyed I guess.
The user interface is obtrusive and way out of proportion and clutters the screen. This is completely unnecessary. The text is also annoying to read, because it changes colors every second and, yes, this is also too big for the screen.

So, if you still haven’t got the impression that I didn’t enjoy this game then this review is probably worthless to you. But if it did make sense to you then I suggest you stay away from this game. Even if it goes on sale (which shouldn’t take that long if I had to take a guess).
Faith in humanity: lost.

reviewText:
I'm sitting here trying to think of how to review Uriel's Chasm, and it is extremely difficult. Let me start by first saying that I don't think Uriel's Chasm should be given a normal game review, as it is not a normal game, I would even hesitate to call it a game. It is both more and less than a game, it is an experience. It is most definitely not for everyone, it's not even for most people I would surmise; However if you are reading this review you contain that spark of interest, and in which case I recommend that you buy it (it's not very expensive) and try it for yourself.

The game contains 4 levels, the last was added in an update. The gameplay is simplistic, and excepting the last level not very challenging. The game is very short as well, probably about 30 minutes to beat, less once you know what you're doing.  Do not buy this for the gameplay, that is not where the appeal lies. I know that sounds counter-intuitive, but I am a firm believer of games as art; they can be for more than entertainment! I like gameplay just as much as the next gamer, and more than some, but sometimes I want more than empty entertainment. And art is exactly what this game is, make no mistake. The game literally calls itself rubbish, so I feel that people that complain about the gameplay are missing the point entirely.

The graphics are excellent, though primitive, and contain some very memorable images ( the hidden face especially ) that combine with the superb music to create an extremely surreal, trippy, oftentimes quite disturbing aesthetic. I cannot comment on the story other than to say it is 'out there' for sure. It is very obtuse and to me didn't make much sense. I am not the type of person to really read a bunch of stuff into something, I'm not very good at that. I can't deny though that it did conjure up some very powerful emotions, something very few games do.

I could go on and still not be able to describe this game as it is something that needs to be experienced. If you have any interest I urge you to try it, form your own opinion. I feel sad that me and like 5 other ♥♥♥♥ing people like the game.

reviewText:
NOTE : RailSlaveGames does not make mass consumption games. Just check out //N.P.P.D Rush// - The Milk of UltraViolet for a frame of reference before judging this.

That being said, this game is more of an enigma which is placed within a long lost ZX Spectrum cartridge that is then presented to you through a Sega CD game than anything else. It is a user experience rather than a game, one that you should revisit a few times and let it sink in. RailSlaveGames has created a world where every little detail is part of an intentionally obscure story which is up to the user to put it together. Nothing is just handed to you, and that’s the way it should be. More like a journey, Uriel’s Chasm is a trip. The gameplay is something you’re doing while you’re checking out the details and investigating the madness.

Let me try to explain....

In the game portion, you play as Sister Tabitha who has travelled to the edge of space to find out what happened to the Orbital Monastery “Enoch’s Hope”, which seems to be in grasps of “Garden”... some kind of otherworldly beast. The first stage is you bolstering your faith (and your sanity) to encounter “Garden” and hopefully find survivors. The second stage is you making the journey and the third stage has you locating the survivors. Or what is left of them.

This is only half the story. The other half is the story of those playing this game.

See, you’re not the player… nor Sister Tabitha. You’re only an observer.

What you’re watching is more akin to The Ring or The Blair Witch Project than any game you’ve played thusfar. The characters in the video sequences (including the trailer) have found some kind of lost or buried NES or ZX Spectrum cartridge. They’re confused and angry at the game. The developer himself calls the game “rubbish” during one of these sequences as it has no options screen and is confusing, just like the game you’re “playing”. However, they’re almost supernaturally compelled to continue to play the game. It keeps calling to them. By the end… well… that’s up to your interpretation.

What’s nice is that the developer is also very open about this title and already has been addressing issues players have been having with it’s presentation and length. Much like //N.P.P.D Rush//, he’s going to continue to add, refine and deepen the experience. Check the forums occasionally, you’ll be glad you did.

...and the music is FANTASTIC. It’s gritty and edgy at parts, while completely environmental and entrancing at others. The vocal tracks can best be described as “UK style Grunge-Goth & PostPunk”.

Uriel’s Chasm defies conventional logic, as any mindscrew should. Let the dark cartridge take you over. Give your soul to that which should have remained lost (or buried).

reviewText:
Uriel's Chasm is a hallucinatory pilgrimage through familiar worlds of arcade experience that have been transformed, through dream-genius and spirituality that would be hard to fake, into prismatic planes of crackling punk religiosity.  The kaleidoscopic savagery of the game's aesthetics will immediately entrance some players (I was one of those), but many will be so offended (perhaps without knowing why), that they will completely commit to despising Uriel's Chasm -- even missing the fact that it is not just a niche work of art, but a carefully polished item of software.  True, the game is not long, but all four of its worlds play with perfect smoothness.  Especially great are levels 2 and 4:  bite-sized chunks of frenetic BULLET HELL that will set the drums in your veins pounding!  Ah, that demonic presence in the final level!  I thought I could laugh at it during my second playthrough, but its discordant shrieks, its twisted visage -- they had me wearing a stiff coat of gooseflesh through the entire fight!

Rail Slave always puts great music into their games!  If spirit-punk and indie electronica are your bag, you should pick up some of the free music they've got floating around!

Love the game or laugh at it -- your call -- but it deserves to be bought and played!  Uriel's Chasm and games like it are why I am in love with the wild and free new Steam.

reviewText:
Seeing the description of the game and the overwhelming amount of negative reviews, I initially thought that Uriel's Chasm ticked off a bunch of edgy atheist teens who freak out at the mere mention of anything religious. Thankfully, the negativity had little to do with this, but I still was not satisfied with the actual reasons motivating the bad reviews. Upon reading a review which spoke highly of its religious themes, controls and similarity to games of the full motion video era, I decided to buy Uriel's Chasm at the price point of $0.49.

After the first level, it became clear to me that Uriel's Chasm uses the fact that it's a game to create an experience unlike any I have ever had. The gameplay here is incredibly simple and easy to learn. Four out of the five keys used are for directional controls. The sole complication this game provides to the player is the fact that each level plays differently than the last. Any curveballs beyond this would interfere with what this game ultimately achieves.

A menacing atmosphere inundates Uriel's Chasm and it intensifies with each level. I cannot wait to reach its conclusion. I never would have imagined that a tandem of the 2006 YouTube and 32-bit 2D game aesthetics could be used to such frightening effect. Play alone at night for the full experience.

With all of this in mind, this is not a game upon which you are going to spend 100 hours. In fact, it shouldn't take you any more than 2 hours to complete. However, a movie ticket costs $10, and this is a far superior experience compared to anything that's currently showing in the multiplex. I likely would not be as thrilled with the experience if I had purchased at its full price, but it's something that I have to recommend, as this game is something I will remember for quite some time.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

It's nowhere near as brilliant as its developer seems to think, but as a short horror story, it's alright.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed the first 20 minutes of my 25 minutes with Uriel's Chasm. The internal logic of being one of three people Let's Playing a game, the references to unlicensed and morally dubious bible games (that I've played in my youth), and the tampering with bad mixes, MDMA and acid moments...the game needs to be played by people who have experienced the jerky games with strobe effects in their youth, when cases for games had warning for epilepsy, which I'll discuss later on...

Not watched on Youtube or Daily Motion or any similar site but played and experienced otherwise you will detest this. It purposely doesn't play well, you need to be in one the not-so-joke to take anything from it beyond it being a recreation of rubbish games with a lot of twists.

For the sake of not spoiling the game I will not go into any detail on how this admittedly short but purposeful game points you and your mind. Whilst the opening cutscene introducing us to two LPers may make you roll your eyes, stick with it, as you progress through the levels -and please do stick with them and beat them even if you get frustrated at first- you will see messages without context, seemingly unrepresentative but applicable logic, and the impact this has on those of us who come from religious backgrounds, whether it's faded in the past, or whether you stuck by them to this day.

If you read the above and want more details, invest, you'll be glad of it after 30 minutes. Or consider the following: what messages existed in video games when developed by the massively out of touch, or the unforgivably twisted who put forth the worst demands of papacy? This is STILL relevant in and out of religious video games as well. Games such as Hatred exist after all, where the dev team is linked to several Polish hate groups.

Uriel's Chasm sticks true to source material and as all the finer works of art -and all games are art- with a message it's relevant to the world around us right now.

Now, the big bad point, the last boss -which covers up what sounds like Christian Snuff (my future-past ramble-punk project)- was too much. True to traditional crap unlicensed Christian games in gameplay terms but painful to try. Literally painful.

It actually gave me what I refer to as colour rays in my peripheral vision, where strobing and streaks/blotches of light not present in anything I am watching appear at the edge of my vision. I'll continue to describe this in a note at the end of the review just in case you have similar vision problems and should possibly avoid playing the game.*

HOWEVER if you aren't the likes of us who gain migraines or have eye problems, and are one of us who remembers the late 80s/early to mid 90s bootleg religious games you may have accidentally played or been given by a particularly concerning horror movie fearing relative, you MUST play this.

---------------

*HEALTH NOTE: Whilst this may make you remember the old Megadrive/Genesis booklets mentioning epilepsy and vision problems, this isn't a problem with my eyesight that has never been undetected: I've been tested for different forms of epilepsy post-injuries to my eyes/one orbital bone/one eye socket means I have prism in my glasses to help out physical strain with both eyes focusing on exactly the right thing.

Hell, I was at my opticians & my GPs a week ago talking through how nothing had changed for the worse in recent history! And it's never bothered me in video games. Ever. In 21 years of playing (that's not my age for the record, I'm a fair few years older). So please, if you do have existing vision problems or have migraine problems you should consider your purchase carefully.

I would still recommend it but I don't want someone reading this to trigger their own health issues!

reviewText:
Uriel's Chasm is a confusing game to say the least. It contains of 4 stages of different gameplay.

1st Stage - Asteroid type game. You're in a spaceship and have to destroy meteors to find bible pages. You have to keep an eye on your fuel and ammo while avoiding a giant spinning monster roaming around aimlessly. Every time you get a page of the bible you'll get half a screen of text that you have no real time to read so I just left it there.

2nd Stage - A sidescrolling bullethell shooter. The most confusing part about this was the hitboxes, sometimes it seems the  player's head is the hitbox, sometimes it's the entire body (when touching the ground). This part of the game was actually kind of fun since it was somewhat challenging.

3rd Stage - 2D platforming, item collecting. So this time you're walking around, jumping from platform to platform, trying to find the crucified Jesus to hear some nonsensical text. On top of the lack of any real gameplay the screen is constantly spinning around, disorienting the player.

4th Stage - Bullethell boss battle. You're fighting a boss who keeps shooting black and white circles at you. On a black background. So good luck dodging the bullets. Fortunatelly when you die the stage just resets so there's no waiting involved. After defeating the boss you get a screen saying The End" and as far as I know that's the end of the game.

Pros:

+ 2nd and 4th stage are challenging and somewhat fun
+ Controlls are actually pretty okay

Cons:

- Unskippable cutscenes that last around 90 seconds
- Gameplay is all over the place. Some of the stages are challenging and fun while others are dull and boring
- Repetitive music
- Poor or no sound effects
- No continuing after exiting the game

If you have any patience you can complete this game but it's not really worth it other than the trading cards."
